title: Variables (Named Storage Boxes)
simplifierConcept:
Variables are like labeled storage boxes:

Imagine you have boxes to store things:
• Box labeled 'age' contains: 25
• Box labeled 'name' contains: "Alice"
• Box labeled 'price' contains: 19.99

Variables work the same way:
• Each has a NAME (what we call it)
• Each has a VALUE (what's inside)
• Each has a TYPE (what kind of data: number, text, etc.)

You can:
✅ CREATE a variable (make a new box)
✅ STORE a value (put something in)
✅ CHANGE the value (replace what's inside)
✅ USE the value (look at what's inside)

Think: Variable = A named box that holds one piece of data!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: 'int' is the type (whole numbers). 'age' is the name (what we call it). '25' is the value (what's stored). '=' means 'assign' or 'store'.
'string' means text. Name must be in quotes. Use for words, names, sentences - any text!
The + operator joins text and variables together. "Hello " + name becomes "Hello Alice". This is called concatenation.
String interpolation - easier way to mix text and variables. Put $ before quotes, variables in {}. More readable than +!

challenge.instructions:
Create a personal profile using variables!

1. Create variables for:
   - Your name (string)
   - Your age (int)
   - Your favorite number (int)
   - Your height in meters (double, like 1.75)
   - Your city (string)

2. Display each variable
3. Create a sentence using string interpolation that includes at least 3 variables

Example output: "Hi, I'm Alice, age 25, from New York"
challenge.hint: Type name = value; for each variable. Use int for whole numbers, double for decimals, string for text. String interpolation: $"Text {variable}".
commonStickingPoints: Using variable before declaring: Must create variable before using it! int age = 25; THEN Console.WriteLine(age). Can't use 'age' if it doesn't exist yet!
Type mismatch: int age = "25"; is WRONG! int holds numbers not text. int age = 25; is correct (no quotes for numbers).
Redeclaring variable: int age = 25; int age = 30; is ERROR! Can't create same variable twice. Instead: int age = 25; age = 30; (no 'int' the second time).
Forgetting $ for interpolation: "{name}" displays literal {name}. $"{name}" displays the value. Don't forget the $ before the quote!
